Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Three Dimensional Structure of the Nucleon in QCD
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploration of the internal structure of the nucleon, the proton or neutron in the nucleus, is one of the main goals of modern nuclear physics. Our understanding of the nucleon as an interacting system of yet more fundamental particles, quarks and gluons, collectively called partons, is based on the theory of strong interactions, Quantum Chromo Dynamics (QCD). Partons are both confined and moving inside of the nucleon. The exploration of the nucleon structure that incorporates the motion of partons will allow us to gain new information on the three dimensional (3D) structure of the nucleon. Knowing how the constituent parts combine together is essential to understanding the properties of the nucleon that we observe. The PI will work towards an improved phenomenological description of the 3D structure of the nucleon and will develop a web interface server based at PSU Berks to make the results available to researchers and the general public. Undergraduate students will be trained and supported by this project.

The scientific goals of the project are to extract precisely the Transverse Momentum Dependent distribution and fragmentation functions (TMDs) that describe the 3D nucleon structure, from the existing experimental data. TMDs are intimately related to the correlations of parton motion and the spin of the parton and /or the spin of the nucleon and generate Spin Asymmetries in scattering processes. The project is intended to unify existing formalisms of the description of the 3D nucleon structure, and ultimately explore the origin of the Spin Asymmetries in various processes. The data from past and existing facilities, such as HERMES (DESY), COMPASS (CERN), and Jefferson Lab, BELLE (KEK), BaBar (SLAC), BESIII (Beijing), RHIC (BNL), LHC (CERN), will be used in the studies. The results of the project will help with planning future experiments at Jefferson Lab 12, and a future Electron Ion Collider. The project will also lead to the extraction of fundamental charges of the nucleon, in particular, the nucleon's tensor charge, which is important for searches of Beyond Standard Model (BSM) physics and complements efforts of its calculation in Lattice QCD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this RUI project was to explore the so-called three dimensional momentum and spin structure of the nucleon encoded in the Transverse Momentum Dependent (TMD) distributions. This proposal gave phenomenological and theoretical support to the existing experimental programs at Jefferson Lab, RHIC (BNL), and for the future Electron Ion Collider by providing analysis, explanation of present data and predictions for future measurements. We investigated the origin of Spin Asymmetries, developed new methods of studying the available experimental data in Semi-Inclusive Deep Inelastic Scattering (SIDIS), Drell-Yan (DY), and e+e− annihilation and pp scattering.
More than ten papers were published in top tier scientific journals and many presentations were given at national and international conferences and workshop. Each year undergraduate students were given an opportunity to present either oral or poster presentations at the national APS conferences. QCD Evolution workshop was organized each year and the research topics of the grant were highlighted in presentations during this workshop. The PI of the grant, Dr. Alexey Prokudin, organized and taught at international graduate summer schools: The 2019 CFNS Summer School on the Physics of the Electron Ion Collider (EIC) and 2018 National Nuclear Physics Summer School at Yale.
The so-called TMD and twist-3 factorizations investigate fundamental quantum mechanical correlations of multiparton states in the nucleon wave function and are believed to yield a unified picture of spin asymmetries in hard processes. The prove of factorization itself involves approximations that may or may not be appropriate for particular experimental measurements. It is very important to phenomenologically test the applicability of factorization theorems and theoretically improve factorization proofs, especially in the view of highly precise data from the future and existing experiments. The PI performed studies dedicated to the improvement of applicability of TMD factorization theorems in the region of low-Q. The PI performed a detailed analysis of sub-leading asymmetries in SIDIS and Drell-Yan. This study solved a long-standing problem of connection of TMD and twist-3 factorization for sub-leading twist asymmetries.
The ultimate way to proof the unified origin of spin asymmetries is to perform a global QCD analysis of all polarized observables from SIDIS, Drell-Yan, hadron pair production in e+e− annihilation, and polarized proton-proton scattering, to this end the PI has developed numerical methods of performing the data analysis and performed analysis of the data from SIDIS and e+e-. Spin asymmetries in proton proton scattering were studied than and the predicted asymmetries were in a very good agreement with the observed ones, hinting at the unified picture.The Sivers functions were extracted from the available experimental data and were shown to be compatible with the expected sign change in SIDIS and Drell-Yan. The confirmation of the sign change of Sivers functions is the common goal of NSF and DOE and the research supported by this grant has shown the first hints on this confirmation.The PI has also studied theoretical connection of Sivers functions and Qui-Sterman matrix element. This relation makes the connection between collinear twist-3 and TMD factorizations.
The PI reported in Phys. Rev. Lett., the first global QCD analysis of the quark transversity distributions of the nucleon from SIDIS measurements with constraints on the isovector tensor charge from lattice QCD, using a new Monte Carlo method. The results for gT showed good agreement and improvement of extracted tensor charge and the lattice calculations.
The PI Engaged in activities to involve minorities in STEM education: The PI presented lectures and a hands-on workshops during the 20th and 21st annual PSU Berks STEM Careers with Math Options Conference in 2018 and 2019, where than 300 female seventh-grade students and their chaperones attended the conference. Disseminated new research advances and results widely to general public: The PI gave the sixth annual George J. Losoncy Lecture in Physics and Astronom in 2017. This lecture is the biggest event in physics and astronomy at PSU Berks and is open to general public.
Mentored minority and female students successfully: The PI worked with 8 research students in the previous 3 years. One of the PI’s research students is a female student, two students are military veterans, and one student is an African-American minority student.Stimulated undergraduate students to develop research and outreach skills: Several students of the PI gave poster presentations at APS meetings and other occasions, and were awarded prestigious PSU and national (REU NSF) grants to perform research with the PI and scientists from Jefferson Lab.
Mentored two graduate students, S. Bastami (Uconn), C. Flore (University of Cagliari, Italy); and one postdoc Dr. D. Pitonyak, who became a faculty at Lebanon Valley College in 2018.
Offered research courses each semester for undergraduate students. They studied the modern Bayesian statistical methods and data analysis, learned programming in Python, and working in Linux environment. Learning these kind of tools was helpful to students in continuation of their STEM careers.
